title: Poverty
subtitle: More than 700 million people live in extreme poverty, with less than US$1.90 a day
facts: Sub-Saharan Africa represents the majority of people living with less than $1.90 a day.
8% of employed workers and their families worldwide lived in extreme poverty.
Globally, there are 122 women aged 25 to 34 living in extreme poverty for every 100 men of the same age group.
High poverty rates are often found in small, fragile and conflict-affected countries.
One out of five children live in extreme poverty.
55% of the world’s population have no access to social protection.
Only 41% of women giving birth received maternity cash benefits.

events.title: Oxfam
events.firstParagraph: Is a global movement of millions of people who believe that poverty isn't inevitable, in a world rich in resources.
events.seconParagraph: Working on 67 countries this movement acts in different fields like: water, health and education, women's empowerment, access to work and equality.

title: Hunger
subtitle: Poor nutrition causes nearly half (45%) of deaths in children under five – 3.1 million children each year
facts: More than 821 million people are undernourished.
The majority of the world’s hungry people live in developing countries, where 12.9% of the population is undernourished.
Sub-Saharan Africa is the region with the highest prevalence of hunger, where 237 people are undernourished.
149 million children under 5 years of age (22% of the global under-5 population) are chronically undernourished
Up to 80% of food consumed in a large part of the developing world is provided bu 500 million small farms worldwide

events.title: Action against Hunger
events.firstParagraph: Is an organization dedicated to save the lives of malnourished children. They ensure everyone can access clean water, food, training and healthcare.
events.seconParagraph: Action Against Hunger's teams work across nearly 50 countries, to fight against hunger.

events.title: Rise Against Hunger
events.firstParagraph: Rise Against Hunger has the vision of a world without hunger. They provide food and life-changing aid to the world’s most vulnerable.
events.seconParagraph: They served around of 537 million meals packaged in 78 different countries.

events.title: Hunger Free America
events.firstParagraph: Is an organization dedicated to make America hunger free, a country with more than 37 million people struggling against hunger.
events.seconParagraph: They provide free food and assistance in New York City.

title: Health
subtitle: More than 5 million children die before their fifth birthday each year
facts: Children born into poverty are almost twice as likely to die before the age of five as those from wealthier families.
77.3 million people have become infected with HIV since the start of the epidemic.
35.4 million people have died from AIDS-related illnesses since the start of the epidemic.
Tuberculosis remains the leading cause of death among people living with HIV.
In Eastern Asia, Northern Africa and Southern Asia, maternal mortality has declined by around two-thirds.
The global malaria incidence rate has fallen by an estimated 37% and the mortality rates by 58%.
areasCaption: By Our World In Data - https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/health-protection-coverage, CC BY 3.0, Link

events.seconParagraph: They work in <strong>9 different countries, to provide access to healthcare for low-resource and medically underserved families around the world.

events.title: GVI

title: Education
subtitle: 617 million youth worldwide lack basic mathematics and literacy skills
facts: Enrolment in primary education in developing countries has reached 91% but 57 million primary age children remain out of school.
Sub-Saharan Africa represents more than half of children that have not enrolled in school.
262 million children remain out of school.
750 million adults still remain illiterate.
Two thirds of the illiterate adults are women.
1 out 5 children between 6 adn 17 years are not attending school.

title: Water and Sanitation
subtitle: At least 892 million people continue to practice open defecation
facts: 1 in 4 health care facilities lacks basic water services.
Half of the world’s population is already experiencing severe water scarcity at least one month a year.
785 million people remain without even basic drink water services.
2 billion people live in countries experiencing hight water stress.
2.4 billion people lack access to basic sanitation services, such as toilets or latrines.
2 out 5 people worldwide do not have a basic handwashing facility with soap and water ate home.

title: Climate Change
subtitle: Climate-related and geophysical disasters claimed an estimated 1.3 million lives between 1998 and 2017
facts: From 1880 to 2012, average global temperature increased by 0.85°C.
Oceans have warmed, the amounts of snow and ice have diminished and sea level has risen.
Global emissions of carbon dioxide (CO2) have increased by almost 50 per cent since 1990.

Given current concentrations and on-going emissions of greenhouse gases, it is likely that by the end of this century, the increase in global temperature will exceed 1.5°C compared to 1850 to 1900 for all but one scenario.
Average sea level rise is predicted as 24 – 30cm by 2065 and 40-63cm by 2100.
